items.title: How Last Samurai Standing adds kinetic action to the Battle Royale formula
items.author: Geoffrey Bunting
items.summary:
- Junichi Okada stars as producer and action designer, guiding fight design from script to screen and coordinating with camera, wardrobe, makeup and editing for coherence.
- A former pop star and martial artist, he blends Kali/Jeet Kune Do with jiujitsu and dance training to shape rhythm, dō and ma in action and storytelling.
- In a bank vault duel with Sakura, the sequence unfolds in three phases—still opening take, escalating violent arc, weary final stalemate—showing concept-driven, collaborative choreography.

items.title: The Vergecast RAM Holiday Spec-tacular
items.author: David Pierce
items.summary: - Overview of RAM's history, why it enabled modern PCs, and how AI-driven demand is driving prices.\n- Hosts and guests discuss market dynamics, chip supply, and RAM shortages, plus RAM-themed games.\n- Look ahead to 2025–2026 AI RAM dynamics and a CES 2026 Vergecast live show.

items.title: How AI broke the smart home in 2025
items.author: Jennifer Pattison Tuohy
items.summary:
- A 2025 Alexa Plus setback shows reliability gaps in AI smart homes, with conversational upgrades failing at basic tasks like lights and routines.
- LLMs are more conversational but less predictable, needing precise API calls and in‑memory logic, causing glitches and cross-model inconsistency.
- The piece contrasts risk-taking tech culture with the need to tame language models, urging more dependable smart homes and informed decisions.

items.title: The year the government broke
items.author: Lauren Feiner
items.summary:
- TikTok’s fate highlighted checks and balances fraying: a ban bill tied to divestment, a Supreme Court ruling, a Biden-to-Trump pivot, and a promised US sale by Jan 22, 2026, prompting doubt about compliance and governance gaps.
- DOGE under Musk triggered 43 days of government disruption: workforce cuts, a hollowed soft power abroad, data access concerns, and threats over late-night jokes; FCC license actions and ICE raids diverted resources from investigations.
- Despite upheaval, courts blocked Trump-era policies and public pushback grew (No Kings rallies, Tesla showrooms protests), signaling civic engagement; looking to 2026, midterms may decide who can restore order and reveal the depth of the cracks.

items.title: Apple fined $116 million over app privacy prompts
items.author: Jess Weatherbed
items.summary:
- AGCM fines Apple over ATT terms, claiming the policy burdens data collection and harms third‑party apps by requiring double consent.
- Apple's own apps can obtain permission in a single tap; the measure is seen as unilateral and potentially harmful to partners.
- This follows similar French scrutiny; Apple intends to appeal, defending privacy protections.

items.title: Dometic makes a better portable water faucet
items.author: Thomas Ricker
items.summary:
- Recon 360 is a battery-powered upgrade to the Go Faucet, with two mechanical buttons, auto-shutoff at 90 seconds or 1.5/3 L, USB-C charging, ~150 L of battery life, and a 360° rotating base for easier placement.
- Hose and CPC connections attach to Go Jug, Recon Hardside Coolers, or third-party jerry cans; magnets help secure it and reduce spills, with a bright LED light and a lower-pitched low-flow mode.
- Priced at $149.99 vs $99.99 for the Go Faucet; Verge says the Recon 360 fixes many complaints and is worth the extra cost, despite cheaper options.

items.title: The FCC’s foreign drone ban is here
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- The FCC added foreign-made drones to the Covered List, effectively barring new imports unless DoD or DHS approves them.
- A National Security Determination found foreign UAS could enable surveillance, data exfiltration, or destructive ops; existing DJI products remain usable.
- Owners can still use current drones and removals are possible; other covered items include Huawei, ZTE, and Kaspersky; FCC chair says UAS support safety and innovation.

items.title: The 60 Minutes report on CECOT that Bari Weiss censored is now internet contraband
items.author: Elizabeth Lopatto
items.summary:
- The Verge reports a nearly 14-minute 60 Minutes segment on CECOT detainees alleging torture that was censored by Bari Weiss after reviews. 
- It ties deportations to Trump-era fee deals, noting about 288 detainees and distribution gaps with some viewers using VPN or recordings. 
- The piece casts the controversy as a test of CBS independence, with NYT/ WaPo coverage and Weiss/Skydance links cited.

items.title: ChatGPT’s yearly recap sums up your conversations with the chatbot
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- The Year in Review rolls out with personal usage stats and a pixel-art image reflecting topics you discussed.
- It shows metrics like total messages, a visual collage of interests, chat style, and the day you sent the most messages.
- You get an archetype (e.g., The Producer) and a custom award, with country rollout and a permission to reference past conversations.

items.title: Call of Duty, Titanfall developer Vince Zampella has died at age 55
items.author: Jay Peters

items.title: Bitcoin does cultural diplomacy in a dive bar
items.author: Tina Nguyen

items.title: Pirate library rips 86 million of the most popular songs on Spotify
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary: - Anna's Archive claims to have ripped ~86 million Spotify tracks (≈37% of catalog, ~99.6% of listens) for a preservation archive.\n- Spotify says it disabled nefarious accounts, added safeguards against anti-copyright attacks, and monitors activity with partners.\n- The case underscores tensions between digital preservation and copyright enforcement, potentially driving new security measures in streaming.

items.title: Birdfy’s Hum Bloom captures 120fps slow motion footage of hummingbirds
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- Hum Bloom: 8MP camera, 4K at 20 fps and 1080p up to 120 fps, with a hydraulic pump to keep the nectar bulb in frame as birds hover.
- Feeder Vista: self-standing with back-to-back cameras for 14MP panoramic stills or 6K 360° video; 2K supports 120 fps; pneumatic seed dispenser.
- Both use OrniSense AI to identify visiting birds; release planned for Q2 2026 with undisclosed pricing.

items.title: Indie Game Awards retracts Expedition 33 prizes due to generative AI
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- The Indie Game Awards rescinded Expedition 33's Game of the Year and Debut Game prizes after confirming Sandfall Interactive used generative AI in development.
- Game of the Year was awarded to Blue Prince; publisher Raw Fury says there was no AI involvement and it was built with human input.
- The Vanguard award for Chantey (tied to ModRetro/Gortyn Code) was also retracted; IGAs will continue navigating AI issues in a Gen AI era.

items.title: Netflix doesn’t stream its ‘Originals’ forever, here are some that may leave in 2026
items.author: Andrew Liszewski

items.title: The Beats Studio Pro headphones are $200 off today
items.author: Barbara Krasnoff
items.summary: - Beats Studio Pro headphones drop to $149.99 at Best Buy through December 22, down from $349.99, with noise cancellation, transparency mode, and USB-C 24-bit/48-kHz audio. - The Verge Deals roundup also highlights Pixel 10 Pro/XL discounts (up to $100 off with codes PIXEL10) along with a $30 MagSafe Charger and Kindle Paperwhite at $134.99. - Krasnoff notes these weekly bargain updates are part of Verge Deals ahead of Christmas.

items.title: Instacart scraps AI pricing tests that made some products more expensive
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary: - Instacart ends its AI-powered pricing tests using Eversight, which created price gaps for identical items at the same store.\n- Going forward prices can vary by store but not due to supply/demand, demographics, or personal shopping data.\n- The move follows FTC scrutiny and a $60M settlement over deceptive practices; retailers may not use Eversight for pricing tests anymore.

items.title: Chipwrecked
items.author: Elizabeth Lopatto
items.summary: - Nvidia-dominated GPU loans back neoclouds (e.g., CoreWeave), using GPUs as collateral with 50–110% LTV and risk of repossession if values fall. - Private credit, SPVs, and asset-backed securitizations drive the boom; mispricing risk could ripple to banks and customers, entrenching Nvidia. - GPU depreciation is contested (roughly 3–6 years, around 5); failures could trigger write-downs, depressed prices, and systemic risk for lenders and cloud users.

items.title: Samsung ‘Wide Fold’ rumored to rival Apple’s foldable next year
items.author: Jess Weatherbed
items.summary:
- ET News (Korea) claims Samsung Wide Fold will launch in 2026 with a 4:3 OLED, 5.4" folded / 7.6" unfolded, described as a 'passport' design.
- Apple’s foldable iPhone is said to be around 5.3" to 7.7" with a similar 4:3/landscape ratio, possibly like two iPhone Airs joined (per Bloomberg/others).
- Both are expected in Fall 2026; the 4:3 ratio could aid reading and design tasks but may create black bars for video content, a challenge echoed by Samsung’s Z Fold 7.

items.title: It’s finally time to retire the word ‘podcast’
items.author: Andru Marino
items.summary:
- YouTube’s 2025 Recap shows TV clips rival podcasts in reach, blurring lines between podcasts and video formats.
- The industry favors calling programming 'shows' for advertiser appeal, with like/subscribe cues migrating from YouTube.
- Distribution may centralize on YouTube/Netflix; audio-only persists as independent work while publishers reframe productions as shows.

items.title: The best books we read in 2025
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Verge Staff roundup of notable 2025 reads across memoirs, science fiction, and literary fiction, with prices noted for several titles.
- Highlights include SNAFU; Things in Nature Merely Grow; The Dispossessed; The Three-Body Problem; Letters from an Imaginary Country; What Kind of Paradise.
- The piece argues that an arms race of attention-getters fuels a fast, engaging but fractured media environment, urging personalized feeds and updates.

items.title: Honey: all the news about PayPal’s alleged scam coupon app
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- MegaLag's videos accuse Honey of anti-consumer practices, including last-click attribution and replacing affiliate tracking with its own cookie.
- Allegations include targeting minors, collecting data from non-sign-ups, pressuring small businesses to join with private codes, and funding young YouTubers.
- PayPal defends practices; Google tightens Chrome policy; user base declines; related class-action suits are underway.

items.title: Frozen Waymos backed up San Francisco traffic during a widespread power outage
items.author: Richard Lawler

items.title: Some of our favorite gifts will cost you less than $25
items.author: Brandt Ranj

items.title: You need to listen to these Christmas deep cuts
items.author: Terrence O’Brien
items.summary: - Ten non-obvious Christmas tracks spanning moods from downbeat to space-disco to zen synths.\n- Featured artists include Tom Waits, Lindstrøm, Björk, 100 gecs, Fucked Up, TMBG, Low, Magnetic Fields, Sharon Jones & The Dap-Kings.\n- The piece aims to broaden the holiday playlist with inventive, genre-hopping takes.

items.title: The 35 best gifts that your teen will actually use
items.author: Sheena Vasani

items.title: Job killer
items.author: May Jeong
items.summary: - Adaptation of Westlake's The Ax follows Man-su after a layoff as he targets rivals for a job, mixing dark humor with capitalism critique.\n- The Verge emphasizes careful world-building—props, space, and Easter eggs—and notes an AI turn added during development.\n- Jeong's piece highlights Park's resilience, a late-2025 release, and his advice to filmmakers to seek an authentic voice.

items.title: The best thing I bought this year: The Nintendo Switch 2
items.author: Brandt Ranj
items.summary:
- Switch 2 uses a 7.9-inch, 120Hz 1080p display with upscaling to 4K and high refresh rates, for a bigger handheld/TV feel.
- 256GB internal storage is tight; microSD Express expansion is supported, but cards cost more.
- Tears of the Kingdom runs at 4K/60fps on Switch 2; Mario Kart World is native; price starts at $449.99; Nintendo hints more exclusives and ports to come.

items.title: How AIM taught the internet to chat
items.author: David Pierce
items.summary:
- David Pierce previews a Version History episode on AOL's AIM and its rise as a defining chat app.
- It covers AIM’s inside-AOL origins, its cultural impact, and why executives resisted monetizing it.
- It asks what might have happened if AIM had endured in the social-network era.

items.title: 2025: a year in art on The Verge
items.author: Verge Staff
items.summary:
- Verge's 2025 art year spans culture, tech, and politics—from DOGE themes to online privacy and dissident surveillance, with a kaleidoscopic gift-guide, a 50-year Saigon hub, and a TikTok-style influencer hub.
- It highlights early Silicon Valley factory abuses, with two women exposing tech accountability; the piece introduces an 'infinite fringe' of racist memes and lists staff credits.
- The package emphasizes handcrafted textures, bold color, psyops visuals, and a DOGE Cerberus portrait, while urging readers to follow topics and authors.

items.title: Humanoid robots are coming. Eventually?
items.author: Robert Hart
items.summary:
- The Verge's Stepback highlights a global surge in humanoid-robot hype with big investments and demos, but true autonomy remains scarce and many performances are staged or teleoperated.
- Falling prices, real-world data collection (cameras and sensors) and synthetic data spur progress, yet critics warn of a data-driven bubble and few justifiable use cases.
- China's embodied AI push and events like World Humanoid Robot Games signal broad interest, but hardware limits and reliance on teleoperation temper expectations.

items.title: Our favorite stuff of 2025
items.author: David Pierce
items.summary:
- Year-end Installer edition catalogs 2025 favorites (Enshittification; Sony WH-1000XM6; Switch 2; Claude Code; Antinote Mac; The Studio; Echo Dot Max; Hue Essentials; Good Hang; Puzzmo) and Kottke homescreen. 
- Homescreen habits favor stock Apple apps; crowd picks include Keychron Q1 HE, AirPods Pro, Android handhelds, Sun Eater, D&D Daddies, Vision Pro. 
- Pierce closes with thanks, 2026 plans, and themes like malleable software, mall Santas, phone bans, and reader-driven projects.

items.title: The Verge’s 2025 holiday gift guide
items.author: Verge Staff

items.title: Sony’s XM5 headphones and the latest Kindle round out this week’s best deals
items.author: Brandt Ranj
items.summary:
- Sony WH-1000XM5 are $248 on Amazon with a free WF-C700N; 30h playback with ANC, lightweight design, eight mics for calls.
- Kindle 11th-gen is $89.99 (ad-supported) with 6" E Ink, Bluetooth for Audible, up to six weeks battery; Echo Dot Max is $79.99 with Matter/Thread/Zigbee.
- Winter deals include Hollow Knight: Silksong on Steam ($15.99), Lego Up House ($30.39), and Keychron V1 Max keyboard ($95.99); Steam Winter Sale ongoing.

items.title: The best last-minute Christmas gifts you can grab for under $50
items.author: Cameron Faulkner
items.summary:
- A gift guide of practical ideas under $50, spanning home, kitchen, travel and tech.
- Highlights include silk pillowcases, candle warmers, compact blenders, USB-C hubs, AirTags and portable speakers.
- Emphasizes affordability and versatility with items priced roughly $13–$45 for various recipients.

items.title: The LCD Steam Deck is done
items.author: Terrence O’Brien
items.summary:
- Valve has discontinued the Steam Deck LCD 256GB model; it’s out of production and currently out of stock on the US site.
- The Verge notes the current entry-level Steam Deck is the 512GB OLED model at $549, with no comment from Valve when asked.
- Analysts say AI-driven RAM/storage costs may drive the discontinuation, while the handheld PC market remains competitive and unlikely to yield a cheaper rival.

items.title: Dogpile’s puzzles mix Balatro, Tetris, and a pile of puppies
items.author: Ash Parrish
items.summary:
- Dogpile fuses deckbuilding, match-3 puzzle mechanics, and Balatro-inspired twists with a cute, gravity-driven dog pile.
- Merge puppies into larger breeds on a physics grid, using modifiers and grooming upgrades to boost points and synergy.
- Steam release with a cozy vibe, no microtransactions, and round-altering penalties after failures.

items.title: You can buy your Xbox Ally an official pair of anti-drift joysticks
items.author: Sean Hollister
items.summary: - Gulikit, with Asus approval, offers official TMR drift-resistant joysticks for Xbox Ally: US$20, UK£20, and €22 for IT/FR/ES, with January release. - They auto-recognize when swapped and calibrate via Armoury Crate; installation is simple: open, swap modules, reassemble; be careful with ribbon cables. - TMR/magnetic sticks avoid wear-prone potentiometers; drift is mainly addressed by recalibration rather than component wear.

items.title: Friend slop made co-op gaming goofier than ever in 2025
items.author: Stevie Bonifield
items.summary:
- Defines friend slop as humor-first indie co-op games meant to be played with friends, usually under $20, with proximity voice chat and goofy physics.
- Notable titles this year include REPO, Peak, Guilty as Sock!, Lockdown Protocol, Mage Arena, emphasizing shared misadventure over deep story.
- Elden Ring Nightreign is a larger, skill-demanding contrast, while the trend centers on accessibility, affordability, and social play.

items.title: Rivian’s AI pivot is about more than chasing Tesla
items.author: Andrew J. Hawkins
items.summary:
- Rivian unveils an end-to-end autonomy push: own AI chips, Gen 2 sensor suite, and a hands-free driving plan with Autonomy Plus.
- Gen 3 hardware arrives by 2026, lidar later, dual-chip computer (~1600 TOPS), two steering modes, and partnerships to enable Level 4.
- Rivian aims for public-market comparables, a $50/month autonomy subscription, and environmental questions as it races Tesla/Waymo.

items.title: The sold-out Nex Playground made my kids laugh and cry
items.author: Sean Hollister

items.title: Want to link from Google’s app store to your app? That’ll be $2–4 per install
items.author: Sean Hollister
items.summary:
- AB and ECL: ECL would charge $2.85/app or $3.65/game within 24h of an off-Play download, plus 20% IAP and 10% subs; AB: 25% IAP and 10% subs (effectively 20% IAP, 5% subs).
- Enrollment requires Google review, a Google API, and 24h reporting; fees not yet collected and reporting not required now, but may later.
- Epic Games backs the deadline but opposes future fees; Jan 22 hearing precedes possible worldwide Google-Epic settlement with lower fees.

items.title: Google is part of Movies Anywhere again
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- Google Play and YouTube purchases can once again sync to Movies Anywhere after a brief outage, with re-enabled retailer support.
- Users must reconnect their Google account for purchases to surface in Movies Anywhere; some received an email with a reconnect button.
- The retailer page lists Google and Disney as participating; no official comments yet from Google or Disney.

items.title: Did a publisher’s slip-up reveal smaller Switch 2 cartridges?
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- ININ Games briefly referenced two smaller Switch 2 cartridge sizes, then removed the claim and said there was no official Nintendo announcement.
- ININ will release the physical Switch 2 version with a €10 surcharge; Nintendo did not comment; cost and memory sizes are cited as reasons.
- A Brazilian journalist cited Arc System Works leaks about two formats (64GB cartridge and game-key card); analysts say memory costs influence decisions.

items.title: Gemini isn’t replacing Google Assistant on Android just yet
items.author: Emma Roth
